title: How to Evaluate Automatic Speech Recognition: Comparing Different Performance and Bias Measures
author: Tanvina Patel (Delft University of Technology), Wiebke Hutiri (Sony AI), Aaron Yi Ding (Delft University of Technology), Odette Scharenborg (Delft University of Technology), ...
relevance_why: The paper discusses bias evaluation in Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) systems, which is crucial for creating fair and effective AI in speech-related tasks, aligning well with my research focus on audio processing.
background: The paper addresses the performance and bias in ASR systems across diverse speaker groups, including children and non-native speakers.
contribution: This paper introduces a comprehensive evaluation framework for ASR systems, incorporating multiple performance metrics and bias measures to better assess model effectiveness for diverse speaker demographics.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous ASR bias evaluations primarily used average error rates, which did not adequately capture disparities among speaker groups.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work utilizes a variety of performance metrics and bias measures, providing a more nuanced understanding of ASR performance across different demographics.

key_innovation: The framework combines traditional error metrics with sophisticated bias measures that allow for a cross-demographic evaluation of ASR systems.
real_world_impact: The findings can improve the design of ASR systems, resulting in more inclusive technologies that better serve diverse user groups, such as children and non-native speakers.
limitations: The paper mentions that its proposed meta-measures may still exhibit biases, particularly when group sizes are unequal.

new_terms.Word Error Rate (WER): **Word Error Rate (WER)** is a common metric used to evaluate the performance of speech recognition systems, calculated based on the number of incorrect words in the transcription.
new_terms.bias measures: **Bias measures** are statistical tools used to quantify disparities in performance across different demographic groups within machine learning systems.
